section.title: The one-parameter family of catenaries through a point
section.p:
Our next step is to determine the number and the character of the catenaries which pass through the two given points 1 and 2. The plan is to find the equation of the one-parameter family of these catenaries passing through the point 1, and then to determine how many of them pass through the second point 2. The equation y_1 = b \cosh \frac{x_1-a}{b} is the condition that the catenary shall pass through the point 1. It is satisfied, as one readily verifies, when a and b are expressed in terms of a new parameter \alpha in the form
a=x_{1}-y_{1} \frac{\alpha}{\cosh \alpha}, \quad b=\frac{y_{1}}{\cosh \alpha},
and the family of catenaries through the point 1 is therefore
y=\frac{y_{1}}{\cosh\alpha} \cosh\left(\alpha+\frac{x-x_{1}}{y_{1}} \cosh \alpha \right)=y(x, \alpha),
where y(x, \alpha) is simply a convenient symbol for the more complicated expression preceding it.

In deducing the properties of the one-parameter family of catenaries through the point 1, we shall need the first and second derivatives with respect to x and \alpha of the function y(x, \alpha) defined in . Derivatives with respect to x will be denoted by primes and with respect to \alpha by subscripts, while the subscript 1 will be used to designate values of x, y, y' at the point 1. If we remember the formulas
\frac{d}{du} \cosh u = \sinh u, \quad \frac{d}{du} \sinh u = \cosh u
mentioned above, we find readily the values
y \amp= \frac{y_1}{\cosh \alpha} \cosh\left(\alpha + \frac{x - x_1}{y_1} \cosh \alpha \right) = y (x, \alpha) y' \amp= \sinh \left(\alpha + \frac{x-x_1}{y_1} \cosh\alpha\right), \quad y_1' = \sinh \alpha y_\alpha \amp= \frac{y' \cdot y_1'}{\cosh \alpha} \left(x - \frac{y}{y'} - x_1 + \frac{y_1}{y_1'}\right),
where in calculating the last derivative hyperbolic sines and cosines have been replaced except in one instance by their values in terms of y, y', y_1 , y_1' from the first three equations.
